node.contents: I came across some interesting code in java.lang.Class#newInstance0:

astNode.text: I came across some interesting code in java.lang.Class#newInstance0:

elements.contents: // Run constructor try { return tmpConstructor.newInstance((Object[])null); } catch (InvocationTargetException e) { Unsafe.getUnsafe().throwException(e.getTargetException()); // Not reached return null; }

node.contents: Check out the Unsafe.getUnsafe().throwException statement. It looks like a checked exception is being thrown from a method which doesn't declare it to be thrown!

astNode.text: Check out the Unsafe.getUnsafe().throwException statement. It looks like a checked exception is being thrown from a method which doesn't declare it to be thrown!

node.contents:
Why did they do this?
If the Sun developers can use this technique, is it ok for us to do so as well?

astNode.text:
Why did they do this?
If the Sun developers can use this technique, is it ok for us to do so as well?

node.contents: There is an interesting blog on Avoiding Checked Exeptions by Don Schwarz. Thanks for sharing.

astNode.text: There is an interesting blog on Avoiding Checked Exeptions by Don Schwarz. Thanks for sharing.

node.contents: I'm not entirely sure, but I expect there was a really good reason. (When you drill down through the layers, reflective invocation involves some extremely tricky things ...)

astNode.text: I'm not entirely sure, but I expect there was a really good reason. (When you drill down through the layers, reflective invocation involves some extremely tricky things ...)

node.contents: If the Sun developers can use this technique, is it ok for us to do so as well?

astNode.text: If the Sun developers can use this technique, is it ok for us to do so as well?

node.contents: I'd say no ... unless you have a really, really good reason. Methods that throw checked exceptions without declaring them are violating the principle of least surprise. Think of the poor guy who might have to debug your code in a critical production system at 3am.

astNode.text: I'd say no ... unless you have a really, really good reason. Methods that throw checked exceptions without declaring them are violating the principle of least surprise. Think of the poor guy who might have to debug your code in a critical production system at 3am.

node.contents: Just cos' some Sun engineer decided something was a good idea in a particular context, doesn't necessarily make it a good idea in general.

astNode.text: Just cos' some Sun engineer decided something was a good idea in a particular context, doesn't necessarily make it a good idea in general.

node.contents: The problem with using the Unsafe class is that it is for internal use only, and doesn't have a defined interface and IS different for different platforms.

astNode.text: The problem with using the Unsafe class is that it is for internal use only, and doesn't have a defined interface and IS different for different platforms.

node.contents: You can achieve the same thing using standard calls. (Though deprecated)

astNode.text: You can achieve the same thing using standard calls. (Though deprecated)

node.contents: With Java and generics, you can profit from type erasure and just throw any exception with this simple trick:

astNode.text: With Java and generics, you can profit from type erasure and just throw any exception with this simple trick:

elements.contents: public class Test { public static void main(String[] args) { doThrow(new SQLException()); } public static void doThrow(Exception e) { Test.<RuntimeException> doThrow0(e); } @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") public static <E extends Exception> void doThrow0(Exception e) throws E { throw (E) e; } }

units.rawText: public class Test { public static void main(String[] args) { doThrow(new SQLException()); } public static void doThrow(Exception e) { Test<RuntimeException> doThrow0(e); } @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") public static <E extends Exception> void doThrow0(Exception e) throws E { throw (E) e; } }
